title-group.article-title: Book Review: Tricks With Your Head: Hilarious Magic Tricks and Stunts to Disgust and Delight

contrib.aff: Creighton University School of Medicine, Omaha, Nebraska

article-meta.product: King M Levy M. Tricks With Your Head: Hilarious Magic Tricks and Stunts to Disgust and Delight. New York, NY: Three Rivers Press; 2002. pp. $12.00. ISBN 978-0-609-80591-6.

body.p: One of the issues confronting child neurologists is the low self-esteem and poor social skills of many of the school-age patients seen in day-to-day practice. Generally, the Journal of Child Neurology does not publish reviews of books more than two years old. However, I came across this little text while assisting (being victimized by?) the magician Mac King at “The Mac King Comedy Magic Show” in Las Vegas, Nevada (Figure 1). Mac King has participated with the Barrow Neurological Institute researchers Stephen L. Macknik and Susana Martinez-Conde in development of the new field of neuromagic (http://www.sleightsofmind.com/).1 –3 This book is meant for school-age children to learn magic tricks to astound friends. The tricks require little in the way of props, and some are easy to master. Developing an ability to perform a few simple magic tricks could be a good means for socially awkward children to improve their peer interactions. Those who become interested in expanding their magic repertoire might also find additional hints at the Mac King Shop (http://www.mackingshop.com/).
